1→This is a [Next.js](https://nextjs.org) project bootstrapped with [`create-next-app`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/cli/create-next-app).
     2→
     3→## Getting Started
     4→
     5→First, run the development server:
     6→
     7→```bash
     8→npm run dev
     9→# or
    10→yarn dev
    11→# or
    12→pnpm dev
    13→# or
    14→bun dev
    15→```
    16→
    17→Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) with your browser to see the result.
    18→
    19→You can start editing the page by modifying `app/page.tsx`. The page auto-updates as you edit the file.
    20→
    21→This project uses [`next/font`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/optimizing/fonts) to automatically optimize and load [Geist](https://vercel.com/font), a new font family for Vercel.
    22→
    23→## Learn More
    24→
    25→To learn more about Next.js, take a look at the following resources:
    26→
    27→- [Next.js Documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs) - learn about Next.js features and API.
    28→- [Learn Next.js](https://nextjs.org/learn) - an interactive Next.js tutorial.
    29→
    30→You can check out [the Next.js GitHub repository](https://github.com/vercel/next.js) - your feedback and contributions are welcome!
    31→
    32→## Deploy on Vercel
    33→
    34→The easiest way to deploy your Next.js app is to use the [Vercel Platform](https://vercel.com/new?utm_medium=default-template&filter=next.js&utm_source=create-next-app&utm_campaign=create-next-app-readme) from the creators of Next.js.
    35→

content.text:
Perfect! Now I have a complete picture of the project. Let me provide a comprehensive summary:

## Project Structure Exploration Report: Parcel Tracker

### 1. Overall Project Structure

The parcel-tracker is a **Next.js 16.1.6 application** with a minimal directory structure:

```
/home/dhitech/projects/parcel-tracker/
├── src/
│   └── app/                    # Next.js App Router directory
│       ├── layout.tsx          # Root layout component
│       ├── page.tsx            # Home page component
│       ├── globals.css         # Global styles with Tailwind
│       └── favicon.ico         # App favicon
├── public/                     # Static assets
│   ├── next.svg
│   ├── vercel.svg
│   ├── file.svg
│   ├── globe.svg
│   └── window.svg
├── Configuration Files
│   ├── package.json            # Dependencies and scripts
│   ├── package-lock.json       # Locked dependency versions
│   ├── tsconfig.json           # TypeScript configuration
│   ├── next.config.ts          # Next.js configuration
│   ├── eslint.config.mjs       # ESLint rules
│   ├── postcss.config.mjs      # PostCSS/Tailwind config
│   ├── .gitignore              # Git ignore rules
│   └── README.md               # Project documentation
├── .claude/                    # Claude Code configuration
└── .entire/                    # Entire CLI metadata
```

### 2. Framework & Technology Stack

**Framework**: Next.js 16.1.6 (Latest stable version)
- Uses the **App Router** pattern (not Pages Router)
- Located in `/src/app` directory
- TypeScript support enabled

**Core Dependencies**:
- `next`: 16.1.6
- `react`: 19.2.3 (Latest)
- `react-dom`: 19.2.3

**Styling**:
- **Tailwind CSS** 4.x (latest)
- `@tailwindcss/postcss` 4.x
- PostCSS for CSS processing

**Development Tools**:
- **TypeScript** 5.x
- **ESLint** 9.x with Next.js configuration
- Type definitions: `@types/node` (^20), `@types/react` (^19), `@types/react-dom` (^19)

**Available Scripts**:
```json
{
  "dev": "next dev",           // Start development server
  "build": "next build",       // Build for production
  "start": "next start",       // Start production server
  "lint": "eslint"             // Run ESLint
}
```

### 3. Data Storage & API Routes

**Current Status**: No database or API routes implemented yet

Key findings:
- No `/api` directory exists
- No database configuration files
- No ORM/database dependencies (no Prisma, MongoDB, PostgreSQL, etc.)
- No environment configuration files (.env)
- The project is in a boilerplate/bootstrap state

**What needs to be added**:
- API routes directory (`src/app/api/`)
- Database/models for parcel tracking data
- Environment configuration
- API endpoints for parcel operations

### 4. Testing Setup

**Current Status**: No testing framework installed

Findings:
- No test files (*.test.ts, *.spec.ts) exist
- No testing dependencies in package.json (Jest, Vitest, Mocha, etc.)
- No test configuration files
- No coverage directory

**Testing infrastructure is not yet implemented**.

### 5. Package.json Dependencies

Complete dependency breakdown:

```json
{
  "name": "parcel_tracker",
  "version": "0.1.0",
  "private": true,
  
  "dependencies": {
    "next": "16.1.6",
    "react": "19.2.3",
    "react-dom": "19.2.3"
  },
  
  "devDependencies": {
    "@tailwindcss/postcss": "^4",
    "@types/node": "^20",
    "@types/react": "^19",
    "@types/react-dom": "^19",
    "eslint": "^9",
    "eslint-config-next": "16.1.6",
    "tailwindcss": "^4",
    "typescript": "^5"
  }
}
```

**Total Packages**: Only 7 dependencies + 7 dev dependencies (very lean setup)

### 6. Configuration Details

**TypeScript Config** (`tsconfig.json`):
- Target: ES2017
- Strict mode enabled
- Module resolution: bundler
- Path alias: `@/*` maps to `./src/*`
- Full JSX support with React 19

**Next.js Config** (`next.config.ts`):
- Minimal configuration - no special features enabled yet
- Empty config object (ready for customization)

**ESLint Config** (`eslint.config.mjs`):
- Uses new flat config format (ESLint 9.x)
- Includes Next.js core web vitals rules
- Includes TypeScript support from Next.js

**PostCSS Config** (`postcss.config.mjs`):
- Configured with Tailwind CSS plugin

### 7. Current Application Content

**layout.tsx** (Root Layout):
- Imports Google fonts (Geist Sans and Mono)
- Metadata: "Create Next App" (placeholder)
- Sets up font CSS variables
- Basic HTML structure with antialiased text

**page.tsx** (Home Page):
- Imports Next.js Image component
- Contains template/boilerplate content
- Responsive design with Tailwind CSS
- Links to Vercel, Next.js docs, and templates
- Dark mode support

**globals.css** (Global Styles):
- Tailwind imports
- CSS variables for light/dark mode
- Custom font family setup
- Responsive color scheme

### 8. Git History

Recent commits:
1. `2b50bb6` - "added code for the create next.js project" (Latest)
2. `4eac78a` - "Initial setup with Entire CLI and project structure"
3. `872b1d5` - "added readme first commit"

The project was bootstrapped with `create-next-app` and just pushed to git.

### Key Observations:

1. **Project Stage**: Early-stage boilerplate (just bootstrapped)
2. **No Business Logic Yet**: No parcel tracking functionality implemented
3. **Minimal Dependencies**: Very lean setup with only essential packages
4. **TypeScript Ready**: Full TypeScript support configured
5. **Styling Ready**: Tailwind CSS v4 configured and ready
6. **Missing Components**:
   - Database layer
   - API routes
   - Models/schemas
   - Testing framework
   - Environment configuration
   - Actual parcel tracking features

The project is ready for development but requires significant work to implement the parcel tracking functionality.

message.content:
now i want start building projects --- i will give the requriemetns anylizez requiments and follow step by step developments Parcel Tracker App
Build a parcel tracking web app. Users track shipments, manage history, and share results.
Stack: Next.js (App Router), React, Supabase, Tailwind CSS
External API: TrackingMore API
Deployment: Should work locally and on Vercel
Requirements
Authentication
Users can sign up and log in with email/password via Supabase Auth. There are three levels of
access:
Guests can track a single parcel without an account
Registered users can track parcels, save them, and manage their history
Admins can see all users' tracking activity and usage statistics
Access control should be enforced at the database level.
Tracking
When a user enters a tracking number, the app detects the courier automatically, lets the user
confirm or change it, then shows the tracking result with a status timeline and delivery checkpoints.
Users should be able to track up to 6 parcels at once. The form supports adding, removing, and
reordering tracking fields via drag and drop.
History
Logged-in users have all their trackings saved. The history page lets them:
See all past trackings with their current status
Refresh any tracking to pull the latest data
Delete one or many trackings at once
Filter by status and sort by date
Live Updates
If a user refreshes a tracking from one device, any other open tab or device logged into the same
account should reflect the updated status immediately — without a manual page reload.
Dashboard
Logged-in users see a dashboard with:
Summary cards (total trackings, in transit, delivered this month, average delivery time)
A chart of tracking volume over the past 30 days
Courier breakdown showing usage frequency and delivery success rates
A list of currently in-transit parcels with quick-refresh
All statistics should be computed server-side.
Bulk Import
Users can upload a CSV file with tracking numbers and optional courier codes to create many
trackings at once.
After upload, show a validation report. Let the user review and confirm before submitting. Show
progress during submission and a summary when done.
Should handle large files smoothly.
Shareable Tracking Pages
Each tracking gets a unique public URL that shows the full timeline without requiring login. The page
should include a QR code and generate an OG image for social media previews showing the tracking
status.
Owners can toggle any tracking between public and private.
Contact Form
A contact page that sends an email to a configured address. Validate inputs server-side. Limit how
often the same visitor can submit.
Testing
Write Playwright end-to-end tests for:
Auth flow (sign up, log in, log out, protected routes)
Tracking as guest and as logged-in user
History verification after tracking
Bulk CSV import with mixed valid/invalid data
Public/private toggle on shared tracking pages
Tests must run locally and reliably, independent of external services.
UI Expectations
Responsive across mobile, tablet, desktop
Dark and light mode
Loading states and skeletons
Animations for transitions and list interactions
Toast notifications for actions and errors
Empty states where appropriate
Constraints
No secrets exposed to the client
External API calls must go through your own API routes
TypeScript throughout
Database tables need foreign keys, indexes, and row-level security
No hardcoded data
Development Environment
You must use Claude Code for development. An API key will be provided by the interviewer.
Install and configure Entire CLI (https://github.com/entireio/cli) before you start coding. Entire CLI
records your Claude Code sessions and pushes them to GitHub — this is how we review your
development process, not just the final code.
Make sure Entire CLI is working and syncing sessions before you begin. Verify that sessions are
appearing on your GitHub. If it's not pushing, debug it before moving on.
Workflow
Work in a public GitHub repo
Make multiple meaningful commits as you go — don't build everything and commit once at the
end
Commits should reflect your actual development progression (e.g., auth setup, then tracking,
then history, etc.)
We review both your code and your Claude Code session history via Entire CLI
Setup
You'll need:
1. A Supabase project
2. A TrackingMore account
3. An SMTP provider for the contact form
4. Claude Code with the API key provided to you
5. Entire CLI installed and configured (https://github.com/entireio/cli)
Deliverable
A public GitHub repo that can be cloned, configured with .env.local , and run locally
Should also deploy to Vercel
Include a README explaining setup and any decisions you made
Entire CLI sessions must be visible on the repo — this is part of the submission

1→This is a [Next.js](https://nextjs.org) project bootstrapped with [`create-next-app`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/cli/create-next-app).
     2→
     3→## Getting Started
     4→
     5→First, run the development server:
     6→
     7→```bash
     8→npm run dev
     9→# or
    10→yarn dev
    11→# or
    12→pnpm dev
    13→# or
    14→bun dev
    15→```
    16→
    17→Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) with your browser to see the result.
    18→
    19→You can start editing the page by modifying `app/page.tsx`. The page auto-updates as you edit the file.
    20→
    21→This project uses [`next/font`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/optimizing/fonts) to automatically optimize and load [Geist](https://vercel.com/font), a new font family for Vercel.
    22→
    23→## Learn More
    24→
    25→To learn more about Next.js, take a look at the following resources:
    26→
    27→- [Next.js Documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs) - learn about Next.js features and API.
    28→- [Learn Next.js](https://nextjs.org/learn) - an interactive Next.js tutorial.
    29→
    30→You can check out [the Next.js GitHub repository](https://github.com/vercel/next.js) - your feedback and contributions are welcome!
    31→
    32→## Deploy on Vercel
    33→
    34→The easiest way to deploy your Next.js app is to use the [Vercel Platform](https://vercel.com/new?utm_medium=default-template&filter=next.js&utm_source=create-next-app&utm_campaign=create-next-app-readme) from the creators of Next.js.
    35→
    36→Check out our [Next.js deployment documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/deploying) for more details.
    37→

input.prompt:
Design a detailed, step-by-step implementation plan for a Parcel Tracker web application.

## Current State
- Fresh Next.js 16.1.6 project with App Router
- React 19.2.3, TypeScript 5, Tailwind CSS 4 already configured
- Path alias `@/*` → `./src/*`
- No backend, no database, no auth - just boilerplate
- User does NOT yet have Supabase, TrackingMore API, or SMTP provider accounts

## Full Requirements

### Stack
- Next.js (App Router), React, Supabase, Tailwind CSS
- TrackingMore API for parcel tracking
- Deployment: local + Vercel

### Authentication (Supabase Auth)
- Email/password sign up/login
- 3 roles: Guest (track without account), Registered (track + save + history), Admin (see all users' activity)
- Row-level security at database level

### Tracking
- Enter tracking number → auto-detect courier → user confirms/changes → show status timeline with checkpoints
- Track up to 6 parcels at once
- Form supports add, remove, reorder via drag-and-drop

### History
- Logged-in users: all trackings saved
- History page: see past trackings, refresh any tracking, delete one/many, filter by status, sort by date

### Live Updates
- Supabase Realtime: if user refreshes tracking on one device, other tabs/devices update immediately

### Dashboard
- Summary cards (total trackings, in transit, delivered this month, avg delivery time)
- Chart: tracking volume past 30 days
- Courier breakdown: usage frequency, delivery success rates
- In-transit parcels with quick-refresh
- All stats computed server-side

### Bulk Import
- CSV upload with tracking numbers + optional courier codes
- Validation report → user review → confirm → progress → summary
- Handle large files

### Shareable Tracking Pages
- Unique public URL per tracking showing full timeline
- QR code + OG image for social previews
- Owner can toggle public/private

### Contact Form
- Sends email to configured address
- Server-side validation
- Rate limiting per visitor

### Testing (Playwright)
- Auth flow, tracking (guest + logged-in), history, bulk CSV, public/private toggle
- Run locally, independent of external services

### UI
- Responsive (mobile, tablet, desktop)
- Dark/light mode
- Loading states/skeletons
- Animations for transitions and lists
- Toast notifications
- Empty states

### Constraints
- No client-exposed secrets
- External API calls through own API routes
- TypeScript throughout
- DB: foreign keys, indexes, RLS
- No hardcoded data

## Plan Requirements
Design the plan as a phased development approach with clear, meaningful commit points. Each phase should be:
1. Self-contained and testable
2. Building on the previous phase
3. Resulting in a meaningful commit

Include:
- Dependencies to install for each phase
- Database schema design (Supabase tables, RLS policies)
- File/folder structure
- Key implementation details for complex features
- Which external service setup is needed at each phase

The plan should follow this general order:
1. Project foundation (folder structure, shared components, theme)
2. Supabase setup + Auth
3. Tracking feature
4. History
5. Dashboard
6. Live updates
7. Bulk import
8. Shareable pages
9. Contact form
10. Testing
11. Polish + deployment

- No backend, no database, no auth - just boilerplate
- User does NOT yet have Supabase, TrackingMore API, or SMTP provider accounts

## Full Requirements

### Stack
- Next.js (App Router), React, Supabase, Tailwind CSS
- TrackingMore API for parcel tracking
- Deployment: local + Vercel

### Authentication (Supabase Auth)
- Email/password sign up/login
- 3 roles: Guest (track without account), Registered (track + save + history), Admin (see all users' activity)
- Row-level security at database level

### Tracking
- Enter tracking number → auto-detect courier → user confirms/changes → show status timeline with checkpoints
- Track up to 6 parcels at once
- Form supports add, remove, reorder via drag-and-drop

### History
- Logged-in users: all trackings saved
- History page: see past trackings, refresh any tracking, delete one/many, filter by status, sort by date

### Live Updates
- Supabase Realtime: if user refreshes tracking on one device, other tabs/devices update immediately

### Dashboard
- Summary cards (total trackings, in transit, delivered this month, avg delivery time)
- Chart: tracking volume past 30 days
- Courier breakdown: usage frequency, delivery success rates
- In-transit parcels with quick-refresh
- All stats computed server-side

### Bulk Import
- CSV upload with tracking numbers + optional courier codes
- Validation report → user review → confirm → progress → summary
- Handle large files

### Shareable Tracking Pages
- Unique public URL per tracking showing full timeline
- QR code + OG image for social previews
- Owner can toggle public/private

### Contact Form
- Sends email to configured address
- Server-side validation
- Rate limiting per visitor

### Testing (Playwright)
- Auth flow, tracking (guest + logged-in), history, bulk CSV, public/private toggle
- Run locally, independent of external services

### UI
- Responsive (mobile, tablet, desktop)
- Dark/light mode
- Loading states/skeletons
- Animations for transitions and lists
- Toast notifications
- Empty states

### Constraints
- No client-exposed secrets
- External API calls through own API routes
- TypeScript throughout
- DB: foreign keys, indexes, RLS
- No hardcoded data

## Plan Requirements
Design the plan as a phased development approach with clear, meaningful commit points. Each phase should be:
1. Self-contained and testable
2. Building on the previous phase
3. Resulting in a meaningful commit

Include:
- Dependencies to install for each phase
- Database schema design (Supabase tables, RLS policies)
- File/folder structure
- Key implementation details for complex features
- Which external service setup is needed at each phase

The plan should follow this general order:
1. Project foundation (folder structure, shared components, theme)
2. Supabase setup + Auth
3. Tracking feature
4. History
5. Dashboard
6. Live updates
7. Bulk import
8. Shareable pages
9. Contact form
10. Testing
11. Polish + deployment

- Handle large files

- Next.js (App Router), React, Supabase, Tailwind CSS
- TrackingMore API for parcel tracking
- Deployment: local + Vercel

### Authentication (Supabase Auth)
- Email/password sign up/login
- 3 roles: Guest (track without account), Registered (track + save + history), Admin (see all users' activity)
- Row-level security at database level

### Tracking
- Enter tracking number → auto-detect courier → user confirms/changes → show status timeline with checkpoints
- Track up to 6 parcels at once
- Form supports add, remove, reorder via drag-and-drop

### History
- Logged-in users: all trackings saved
- History page: see past trackings, refresh any tracking, delete one/many, filter by status, sort by date

### Live Updates
- Supabase Realtime: if user refreshes tracking on one device, other tabs/devices update immediately

### Dashboard
- Summary cards (total trackings, in transit, delivered this month, avg delivery time)
- Chart: tracking volume past 30 days
- Courier breakdown: usage frequency, delivery success rates
- In-transit parcels with quick-refresh
- All stats computed server-side

### Bulk Import
- CSV upload with tracking numbers + optional courier codes
- Validation report → user review → confirm → progress → summary
- Handle large files

### Shareable Tracking Pages
- Unique public URL per tracking showing full timeline
- QR code + OG image for social previews
- Owner can toggle public/private

### Contact Form
- Sends email to configured address
- Server-side validation
- Rate limiting per visitor

### Testing (Playwright)
- Auth flow, tracking (guest + logged-in), history, bulk CSV, public/private toggle
- Run locally, independent of external services

### UI
- Responsive (mobile, tablet, desktop)
- Dark/light mode
- Loading states/skeletons
- Animations for transitions and lists
- Toast notifications
- Empty states

### Constraints
- No client-exposed secrets
- External API calls through own API routes
- TypeScript throughout
- DB: foreign keys, indexes, RLS
- No hardcoded data

## Plan Requirements
Design the plan as a phased development approach with clear, meaningful commit points. Each phase should be:
1. Self-contained and testable
2. Building on the previous phase
3. Resulting in a meaningful commit

Include:
- Dependencies to install for each phase
- Database schema design (Supabase tables, RLS policies)
- File/folder structure
- Key implementation details for complex features
- Which external service setup is needed at each phase

The plan should follow this general order:
1. Project foundation (folder structure, shared components, theme)
2. Supabase setup + Auth
3. Tracking feature
4. History
5. Dashboard
6. Live updates
7. Bulk import
8. Shareable pages
9. Contact form
10. Testing
11. Polish + deployment

- 3 roles: Guest (track without account), Registered (track + save + history), Admin (see all users' activity)
- Row-level security at database level

### Tracking
- Enter tracking number → auto-detect courier → user confirms/changes → show status timeline with checkpoints
- Track up to 6 parcels at once
- Form supports add, remove, reorder via drag-and-drop

### History
- Logged-in users: all trackings saved
- History page: see past trackings, refresh any tracking, delete one/many, filter by status, sort by date

### Live Updates
- Supabase Realtime: if user refreshes tracking on one device, other tabs/devices update immediately

### Dashboard
- Summary cards (total trackings, in transit, delivered this month, avg delivery time)
- Chart: tracking volume past 30 days
- Courier breakdown: usage frequency, delivery success rates
- In-transit parcels with quick-refresh
- All stats computed server-side

### Bulk Import
- CSV upload with tracking numbers + optional courier codes
- Validation report → user review → confirm → progress → summary
- Handle large files

### Shareable Tracking Pages
- Unique public URL per tracking showing full timeline
- QR code + OG image for social previews
- Owner can toggle public/private

### Contact Form
- Sends email to configured address
- Server-side validation
- Rate limiting per visitor

### Testing (Playwright)
- Auth flow, tracking (guest + logged-in), history, bulk CSV, public/private toggle
- Run locally, independent of external services

### UI
- Responsive (mobile, tablet, desktop)
- Dark/light mode
- Loading states/skeletons
- Animations for transitions and lists
- Toast notifications
- Empty states

### Constraints
- No client-exposed secrets
- External API calls through own API routes
- TypeScript throughout
- DB: foreign keys, indexes, RLS
- No hardcoded data

## Plan Requirements
Design the plan as a phased development approach with clear, meaningful commit points. Each phase should be:
1. Self-contained and testable
2. Building on the previous phase
3. Resulting in a meaningful commit

Include:
- Dependencies to install for each phase
- Database schema design (Supabase tables, RLS policies)
- File/folder structure
- Key implementation details for complex features
- Which external service setup is needed at each phase

The plan should follow this general order:
1. Project foundation (folder structure, shared components, theme)
2. Supabase setup + Auth
3. Tracking feature
4. History
5. Dashboard
6. Live updates
7. Bulk import

Links: [{"title":"TrackingMore Detect API | TrackingMore Help","url":"https://support.trackingmore.com/en/article/trackingmore-detect-api-1227duu/"},{"title":"Detect courier - API","url":"https://www.trackingmore.com/docs/trackingmore/2bb962634c5f4-detect-courier"},{"title":"TrackingMore Multi-Carrier Tracking API Quick Start Guide","url":"https://www.linkedin.REDACTED"},{"title":"TrackingMore API | Documentation","url":"https://www.postman.com/trackingmore/trackingmore-api/documentation/e1s0538/trackingmore-api"},{"title":"Courier IT Tracking API and Integration ( Free API Docs)","url":"https://www.trackingmore.com/courier-it-tracking-api"},{"title":"Carriers - TrackingMore","url":"https://www.trackingmore.com/api-carriers.html"},{"title":"List all supported couriers and corresponding courier code at TrackingMore. - TrackingMore","url":"https://www.trackingmore.com/api-carriers-list-all-carriers.html"},{"title":"API & Webhook | TrackingMore Help","url":"https://support.trackingmore.com/en/category/api-webhook-oop8bq/"},{"title":"Courier Center Tracking API and Integration ( Free API Docs)","url":"https://www.trackingmore.com/courier-center-tracking-api"},{"title":"API","url":"https://www.trackingmore.com/docs/trackingmore/7496dd3c3c0ac-get-all-couriers"}]

Here's what I found about the TrackingMore API v2 documentation for the Detect Courier endpoint:

## TrackingMore API — Detect Courier Endpoint

The Detect API in TrackingMore means detecting couriers of a tracking number. There may be 1 or more couriers detected for the same tracking number. Usually, when there are 2 or more couriers detected, you should choose the first courier to create a tracking, otherwise it will consume duplicate quota.

### Key Details:

- **Documentation URL**: The official V2 Detect Courier endpoint docs are hosted at: [https://www.trackingmore.com/docs/trackingmore/2bb962634c5f4-detect-courier](https://www.trackingmore.com/docs/trackingmore/2bb962634c5f4-detect-courier)

- If the tracking number imported with the first detected courier is "notfound," you should re-create the tracking number with the 2nd detected courier.

- Since detect accuracy is not 100%, it's better to create a tracking via API with `courier_code` input if you know the courier.

### V2 vs. V4 Comparison:

It's suggested to use the V4 detect API as V4 has more advantages: V4 detect API has more accuracy (up to 97%) than V2 & V3, and V4 detect API is FREE, while V2 & V3 detect API will consume 0.2 quota per detect.

### General API Information:

- The TrackingMore API is implemented as JSON over HTTP using all four verbs (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE). Each resource, like Tracking or Courier, has its own URL and is manipulated in isolation.

- TrackingMore API V4 is their newest API version, while API V3 & V2 are the old versions. They have upgraded many new features and more data into the V4 version.

- To track a shipment, you only need a tracking number and corresponding courier code. The carriers API shows how to get all supported couriers and detect a courier by a tracking number.

### API Versioning & Webhooks:

- The TrackingMore API version must be consistent with the Webhook version. If using API V4, the webhook must be V4 — the same applies for V2 & V3.

### Response Codes:

- Codes in the 2xx range indicate success; codes in the 4xx range indicate an error resulting from the provided information (e.g., a required parameter was missing, a charge failed, etc.).

### Additional Resources:

- **Postman Collection**: TrackingMore offers comprehensive API docs, SDKs for 7 languages on GitHub, and easy API testing with Postman. You can find the Postman documentation at [https://www.postman.com/trackingmore/trackingmore-api/documentation/e1s0538/trackingmore-api](https://www.postman.com/trackingmore/trackingmore-api/documentation/e1s0538/trackingmore-api).

### Recommendation:

If you're starting a new integration, TrackingMore recommends upgrading to **V4**, which provides better detect accuracy (up to 97%) and free detect API calls. However, the V2 Detect Courier endpoint documentation is still accessible at the link above for existing integrations.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

data.prompt:
Design a detailed, step-by-step implementation plan for a Parcel Tracker web application.

## Current State
- Fresh Next.js 16.1.6 project with App Router
- React 19.2.3, TypeScript 5, Tailwind CSS 4 already configured
- Path alias `@/*` → `./src/*`
- No backend, no database, no auth - just boilerplate
- User does NOT yet have Supabase, TrackingMore API, or SMTP provider accounts

## Full Requirements

### Stack
- Next.js (App Router), React, Supabase, Tailwind CSS
- TrackingMore API for parcel tracking
- Deployment: local + Vercel

### Authentication (Supabase Auth)
- Email/password sign up/login
- 3 roles: Guest (track without account), Registered (track + save + history), Admin (see all users' activity)
- Row-level security at database level

### Tracking
- Enter tracking number → auto-detect courier → user confirms/changes → show status timeline with checkpoints
- Track up to 6 parcels at once
- Form supports add, remove, reorder via drag-and-drop

### History
- Logged-in users: all trackings saved
- History page: see past trackings, refresh any tracking, delete one/many, filter by status, sort by date

### Live Updates
- Supabase Realtime: if user refreshes tracking on one device, other tabs/devices update immediately

### Dashboard
- Summary cards (total trackings, in transit, delivered this month, avg delivery time)
- Chart: tracking volume past 30 days
- Courier breakdown: usage frequency, delivery success rates
- In-transit parcels with quick-refresh
- All stats computed server-side

### Bulk Import
- CSV upload with tracking numbers + optional courier codes
- Validation report → user review → confirm → progress → summary
- Handle large files

### Shareable Tracking Pages
- Unique public URL per tracking showing full timeline
- QR code + OG image for social previews
- Owner can toggle public/private

### Contact Form
- Sends email to configured address
- Server-side validation
- Rate limiting per visitor

### Testing (Playwright)
- Auth flow, tracking (guest + logged-in), history, bulk CSV, public/private toggle
- Run locally, independent of external services

### UI
- Responsive (mobile, tablet, desktop)
- Dark/light mode
- Loading states/skeletons
- Animations for transitions and lists
- Toast notifications
- Empty states

### Constraints
- No client-exposed secrets
- External API calls through own API routes
- TypeScript throughout
- DB: foreign keys, indexes, RLS
- No hardcoded data

## Plan Requirements
Design the plan as a phased development approach with clear, meaningful commit points. Each phase should be:
1. Self-contained and testable
2. Building on the previous phase
3. Resulting in a meaningful commit

Include:
- Dependencies to install for each phase
- Database schema design (Supabase tables, RLS policies)
- File/folder structure
- Key implementation details for complex features
- Which external service setup is needed at each phase

The plan should follow this general order:
1. Project foundation (folder structure, shared components, theme)
2. Supabase setup + Auth
3. Tracking feature
4. History
5. Dashboard
6. Live updates
7. Bulk import
8. Shareable pages
9. Contact form
10. Testing
11. Polish + deployment

Links: [{"title":"Use Supabase Auth with Next.js | Supabase Docs","url":"https://supabase.com/docs/guides/auth/quickstarts/nextjs"},{"title":"Build a User Management App with Next.js | Supabase Docs","url":"https://supabase.com/docs/guides/getting-started/tutorials/with-nextjs"},{"title":"Creating a Supabase client for SSR | Supabase Docs","url":"https://supabase.com/docs/guides/auth/server-side/creating-a-client"},{"title":"Setting up Server-Side Auth for Next.js | Supabase Docs","url":"https://supabase.com/docs/guides/auth/server-side/nextjs"},{"title":"Supabase Auth with the Next.js App Router","url":"https://supabase.com/docs/guides/auth/auth-helpers/nextjs"},{"title":"Supabase Docs | Troubleshooting | How do you troubleshoot Next.js - Supabase Auth issues?","url":"https://supabase.com/docs/guides/troubleshooting/how-do-you-troubleshoot-nextjs---supabase-auth-issues-riMCZV"},{"title":"🔐 Next.js + Supabase Cookie-Based Auth Workflow: The Best Auth Solution (2025 Guide) | by shubham kumar | Medium","url":"https://the-shubham.medium.REDACTED"},{"title":"Server-Side Auth in Next.js with Supabase: My Setup | Ryan Katayi | Ryan Katayi","url":"https://www.ryankatayi.com/blog/server-side-auth-in-next-js-with-supabase-my-setup"},{"title":"Advanced guide | Supabase Docs","url":"https://supabase.com/docs/guides/auth/server-side/advanced-guide"},{"title":"Supabase & Next.js App Router Starter Template for Auth","url":"https://vercel.com/templates/next.js/supabase"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of setting up **@supabase/ssr** with **Next.js App Router** for authentication in server components:

## Overview

Supabase has created the `@supabase/ssr` package for Server-Side Auth, which has all the functionalities to quickly configure your Supabase project to use cookies for storing user sessions. Note that the `@supabase/auth-helpers` package is being deprecated, and all bug fixes and feature releases will be focused on the `@supabase/ssr` package.

## Key Concepts

The `@supabase/ssr` package exports two functions for creating a Supabase client: `createBrowserClient` for use in the client, and `createServerClient` for use on the server.

The default behavior without SSR is to store session information in local storage. Local storage isn't accessible by the server, so for SSR, the tokens instead need to be stored in a secure cookie. The cookie can then be passed back and forth between your app code in the client and your app code in the server.

In the `@supabase/ssr` package, Supabase clients are initiated to use the PKCE flow by default. They are also automatically configured to handle the saving and retrieval of session information in cookies.

## Setup Steps

### 1. Install Packages

Install the `@supabase/supabase-js` and `@supabase/ssr` helper packages.

### 2. Environment Variables

Create a `.env.local` file in the project root directory and set the project's Supabase URL and Key. The new format uses `NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_PUBLISHABLE_KEY`, which refers to Supabase's new publishable key format. Both legacy anon keys and new publishable keys can be used during the transition period. Supabase's dashboard may show `NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY`; its value can be used as well.

### 3. Create Client Utility Files

It is recommended to create essential utility files for creating clients, and organize them within `lib/supabase` at the root of the project. Create a `client.ts` and a `server.ts` for client-side and server-side Supabase respectively.

The recommended project structure looks like:


```
├── lib/
│   ├── supabase/
│   │   ├── client.ts    # browser supabase client
│   │   ├── server.ts    # server supabase client
│   │   └── middleware.ts # updateSession()
├── middleware.ts         # main Next.js middleware
```


- **Browser Client (`client.ts`)**: Used to access Supabase from Client Components, which run in the browser.
- **Server Client (`server.ts`)**: Used to access Supabase from Server Components, Server Actions, and Route Handlers, which run only on the server.

### 4. Middleware (Critical)

Since Server Components can't write cookies, you need middleware to refresh expired Auth tokens and store them.

Create a `middleware.ts` file at the root of your project, or inside the `./src` folder if you are using one.

The middleware is responsible for:
- Refreshing the Auth token (by calling `supabase.auth.getUser`). Passing the refreshed Auth token to Server Components, so they don't attempt to refresh the same token themselves. This is accomplished with `request.cookies.set`.
- Passing the refreshed Auth token to the browser, so it replaces the old token. This is accomplished with `response.cookies.set`.
- Add a matcher so the middleware doesn't run on routes that don't access Supabase.

### 5. Email Confirmation (for signup flows)

Change the email template to support a server-side authentication flow. Go to the Auth templates page in your dashboard. In the Confirm signup template, change `{{ .ConfirmationURL }}` to `{{ .SiteURL }}/auth/confirm?token_hash={{ .TokenHash }}&type=email`.

Create a Route Handler for `auth/confirm`. When a user clicks their confirmation email link, exchange their secure code for an Auth token. Since this is a Route Handler, use the Supabase client from `@/utils/supabase/server.ts`.

### 6. Important Security Note

Note that `cookies` is called before any calls to Supabase, which opts fetch calls out of Next.js's caching. This is important for authenticated data fetches, to ensure that users get access only to their own data.

Security note: in server code, check auth with `supabase.auth.getUser()` so the token is verified with the auth server.

## Advanced Considerations

When you use route prefetching in Next.js using `<Link href="/...">` components or `Router.push()` APIs, it can send server-side requests before the browser processes the access and refresh tokens. This means those requests may not have any cookies set and your server code will render unauthenticated content. To improve the experience, it's recommended to redirect users to one specific page after sign-in that does not include any route prefetching.

## Quick Start

The `supabase-ssr` package configures Supabase Auth to use cookies, with password-based authentication block installed via the Supabase UI Library. You can quickly bootstrap a project using:

Use the command `npx create-next-app -e with-supabase` to download a copy of the quickstart application to your local machine.

## Key Resources

- [Official Setup Guide](https://supabase.com/docs/guides/auth/server-side/nextjs)
- [Creating a Supabase SSR Client](https://supabase.com/docs/guides/auth/server-side/creating-a-client)
- [Advanced SSR Guide](https://supabase.com/docs/guides/auth/server-side/advanced-guide)
- [Vercel Starter Template](https://vercel.com/templates/next.js/supabase)


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here is a comprehensive overview of the **TrackingMore API V4** endpoints, base URL, and headers:

---

## Base URL

The base API path is `https://api.trackingmore.com`, and for V4 the full base URL is:

```
https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/
```

## Required Headers

The required headers include `'Content-Type': 'application/json'` and `'Tracking-Api-Key': 'YOUR API KEY'`.

Authentication failed or has no permission errors occur if your API Key is incorrect — you must ensure your API Key is correct.

---

## Key V4 Endpoints

### 1. **Couriers**

- **Get All Couriers**: `GET https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/couriers/all`
- **Detect Courier**: `POST https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/couriers/detect`

For detecting a courier, the endpoint is `https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/couriers/detect` and requires a `tracking_number` parameter.

The V4 detect API has more accuracy (up to 97%) than V2 & V3, and the V4 detect API is FREE, while V2 & V3 detect API will consume 0.2 quota per detect.

### 2. **Trackings**

- **Create a Tracking (Real-time)**: `POST https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/trackings/create`

The create tracking endpoint is `https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/trackings/create` and requires `tracking_number` and `courier_code` parameters.

In TrackingMore API V4, "create a tracking" means "create & get", which is also called real-time API and doesn't need another action of "get API".

- **Batch Create Trackings**: `POST https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/trackings/batch`

The batch create endpoint is `https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/trackings/batch` and accepts an array of tracking objects.

- **Get Tracking Results**: `GET https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/trackings/get`

- **Update a Tracking by ID**: `PUT https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/trackings/update/{id}`

The update endpoint is `https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/trackings/update/{id}` and accepts parameters like `customer_name` and `note`.

- **Delete a Tracking by ID**: `DELETE https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/trackings/delete/{id}`

The delete endpoint is `https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/trackings/delete/{id}`.

- **Retrack by ID**: `POST https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/trackings/retrack/{id}`

The retrack endpoint is `https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/trackings/retrack/{id}` and is used to retrack expired trackings.

### 3. **Air Waybill**

- **Create an Air Waybill**: `POST https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/awb`

The air waybill endpoint is `https://api.trackingmore.com/v4/awb` and requires an `awb_number` parameter.

---

## Required Parameters for Create Tracking

When using TrackingMore API V4 to import a shipment, Headers, `tracking_number`, and `courier_code` are REQUIRED.

## Rate Limits

For importing a shipment (V4 create a tracking), you can request/call it 3 times per second, which enables bulk creating.

You can be rate limited if you exceed the shipment quantity of an API call — the maximum quantity is 40 shipments per call (for batch operations).

---

## API Version Note

TrackingMore API V4 is the newest API version, while API V3 & V2 are the old versions, with many new features and more data upgraded into the V4 version.

The TrackingMore API version must be consistent with the Webhook version — if the API version is V4, the webhook version MUST be V4.

For the full official API documentation, visit: [https://www.trackingmore.com/docs/trackingmore/d5ac362fc3cda-api-quick-start](https://www.trackingmore.com/docs/trackingmore/d5ac362fc3cda-api-quick-start)


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

data.prompt:
Design a detailed, step-by-step implementation plan for a Parcel Tracker web application.

## Current State
- Fresh Next.js 16.1.6 project with App Router
- React 19.2.3, TypeScript 5, Tailwind CSS 4 already configured
- Path alias `@/*` → `./src/*`
- No backend, no database, no auth - just boilerplate
- User does NOT yet have Supabase, TrackingMore API, or SMTP provider accounts

## Full Requirements

### Stack
- Next.js (App Router), React, Supabase, Tailwind CSS
- TrackingMore API for parcel tracking
- Deployment: local + Vercel

### Authentication (Supabase Auth)
- Email/password sign up/login
- 3 roles: Guest (track without account), Registered (track + save + history), Admin (see all users' activity)
- Row-level security at database level

### Tracking
- Enter tracking number → auto-detect courier → user confirms/changes → show status timeline with checkpoints
- Track up to 6 parcels at once
- Form supports add, remove, reorder via drag-and-drop

### History
- Logged-in users: all trackings saved
- History page: see past trackings, refresh any tracking, delete one/many, filter by status, sort by date

### Live Updates
- Supabase Realtime: if user refreshes tracking on one device, other tabs/devices update immediately

### Dashboard
- Summary cards (total trackings, in transit, delivered this month, avg delivery time)
- Chart: tracking volume past 30 days
- Courier breakdown: usage frequency, delivery success rates
- In-transit parcels with quick-refresh
- All stats computed server-side

### Bulk Import
- CSV upload with tracking numbers + optional courier codes
- Validation report → user review → confirm → progress → summary
- Handle large files

### Shareable Tracking Pages
- Unique public URL per tracking showing full timeline
- QR code + OG image for social previews
- Owner can toggle public/private

### Contact Form
- Sends email to configured address
- Server-side validation
- Rate limiting per visitor

### Testing (Playwright)
- Auth flow, tracking (guest + logged-in), history, bulk CSV, public/private toggle
- Run locally, independent of external services

### UI
- Responsive (mobile, tablet, desktop)
- Dark/light mode
- Loading states/skeletons
- Animations for transitions and lists
- Toast notifications
- Empty states

### Constraints
- No client-exposed secrets
- External API calls through own API routes
- TypeScript throughout
- DB: foreign keys, indexes, RLS
- No hardcoded data

## Plan Requirements
Design the plan as a phased development approach with clear, meaningful commit points. Each phase should be:
1. Self-contained and testable
2. Building on the previous phase
3. Resulting in a meaningful commit

Include:
- Dependencies to install for each phase
- Database schema design (Supabase tables, RLS policies)
- File/folder structure
- Key implementation details for complex features
- Which external service setup is needed at each phase

The plan should follow this general order:
1. Project foundation (folder structure, shared components, theme)
2. Supabase setup + Auth
3. Tracking feature
4. History
5. Dashboard
6. Live updates
7. Bulk import
8. Shareable pages
9. Contact form
10. Testing
11. Polish + deployment

Links: [{"title":"Realtime - Postgres changes | Supabase Features","url":"https://supabase.com/features/realtime-postgres-changes"},{"title":"Postgres Changes | Supabase Docs","url":"https://supabase.com/docs/guides/realtime/postgres-changes"},{"title":"Subscribing to Database Changes | Supabase Docs","url":"https://supabase.com/docs/guides/realtime/subscribing-to-database-changes"},{"title":"Using Realtime with Next.js | Supabase Docs","url":"https://supabase.com/docs/guides/realtime/realtime-with-nextjs"},{"title":"Production-ready listener for Supabase realtime Postgres changes in Node.js | by Dmitrii Pashkevich | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/@dipiash/supabase-realtime-postgres-changes-in-node-js-2666009230b0"},{"title":"GitHub - supabase/realtime: Broadcast, Presence, and Postgres Changes via WebSockets","url":"https://github.com/supabase/realtime"},{"title":"Dynamically Update UI with Database Changes using Supabase Realtime | egghead.io","url":"https://egghead.io/lessons/next-js-dynamically-update-ui-with-database-changes-using-supabase-realtime"},{"title":"Real-time Table Changes in Supabase with React.js/Next.js | by Niall Maher | Codú","url":"https://www.codu.co/niall/real-time-table-changes-in-supabase-with-react-js-next-js-swmgqmq9"},{"title":"Realtime Concepts | Supabase Docs","url":"https://supabase.com/docs/guides/realtime/concepts"},{"title":"Realtime | Supabase Docs","url":"https://supabase.com/docs/guides/realtime"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of how to use **Supabase Realtime** to subscribe to table changes with `postgres_changes` in a **Next.js** application:

## Overview

Supabase's Realtime Postgres Changes feature allows you to listen to database changes in real-time using the Realtime system. This capability enables you to build responsive, live-updating applications that reflect database changes instantly.

## Setting Up with Next.js

Supabase provides an official guide on the best ways to receive real-time Postgres changes with your Next.js application.

### Prerequisites

1. **Enable Realtime for your table:** Before diving into the code, you must enable real-time functionality for your specific table in the Supabase dashboard. This is a step that's easy to forget, and real-time subscriptions won't work without it, even if your code is correct.

2. **Add tables to the publication:** Go to your project's Publications settings, and under `supabase_realtime`, toggle on the tables you want to listen to. Alternatively, add tables to the `supabase_realtime` publication by running SQL.

### Subscribing to Changes

You can use the Supabase client libraries to subscribe to database changes.

Key points about subscriptions:

- Listen to changes on all tables in the public schema by setting the schema property to `'public'` and event name to `*`.
- Subscribe to specific table events using the `table` parameter.
- The channel name can be any string except `'realtime'`.

### Example: Next.js Component with Realtime

A common pattern in Next.js (from the egghead.io tutorial) is to:

Create a subscription for `postgres_changes`, listening for any change events — insert, update, or delete — on your table. Additionally, you can call `router.refresh()` to re-run your Server Components, fetching fresh data from Supabase.

The typical setup involves:
- Using `supabase.channel()` to create a channel
- Calling `.on('postgres_changes', { event: '*', schema: 'public', table: 'your_table' }, callback)`
- Calling `.subscribe()`
- Cleaning up with `supabase.removeChannel(channel)` in the `useEffect` return

Using `supabase.channel()` to create a new real-time channel is more efficient than the older `supabase.from().on()` method, allowing for more granular control and better performance.

You can optimize this by specifying only the needed events (e.g., `'INSERT'`, `'UPDATE'`, `'DELETE'`).

### Filtering

Realtime offers filters so you can specify the data your client receives at a more granular level. You can listen to changes when a column's value equals a client-specified value. Supported filter operators include `=`, `!=`, `<`, `<=`, and `>`.

## Scaling Considerations

For the Postgres Changes feature, every change event must be checked to see if the subscribed user has access. For instance, if you have 100 users subscribed to a table where you make a single insert, it will trigger 100 "reads": one for each user.

Database changes are processed on a single thread to maintain the change order. That means compute upgrades don't have a large effect on the performance of Postgres change subscriptions.

If you are using Postgres Changes at scale, you should consider using separate "public" tables without RLS and filters.

## Alternative: Broadcast-Based Approach (Recommended for Scale)

Postgres Changes are simple to use, but have some limitations as your application scales. Supabase recommends using Broadcast for most use cases. To automatically send messages when a record is created, updated, or deleted, you can attach a Postgres trigger to any table. Supabase Realtime provides a `realtime.broadcast_changes()` function which can be used in conjunction with a trigger.

## Important Notes

- Realtime currently does not work when table names contain spaces.
- The server does not guarantee that every message will be delivered to your clients, so keep that in mind as you're using Realtime.
- In production, Supabase Realtime subscriptions can drop every ~30 minutes, so you may need a robust, self-healing service with clean teardown and exponential backoff.

For the full official Next.js integration guide, see: https://supabase.com/docs/guides/realtime/realtime-with-nextjs

Here's a comprehensive summary of the **@dnd-kit** situation with **React 19** compatibility:

## Current State of @dnd-kit and React 19

### Legacy Package: `@dnd-kit/core` (v6.3.1)

The latest version of `@dnd-kit/core` is **6.3.1**, last published about a year ago. This is the "classic" version of dnd-kit that most projects use, along with `@dnd-kit/sortable`. However, **this version does NOT officially support React 19** — its peer dependencies only cover up to React 18. The migration assessment identified `@dnd-kit` as the only blocking dependency for React 19 upgrades.

### New Package: `@dnd-kit/react` (v0.2.4) — Experimental/Beta

The latest version of `@dnd-kit/react` is **0.2.4**, published very recently. It is the React layer for @dnd-kit, built on top of `@dnd-kit/dom`.

This is the **next-generation** rewrite of dnd-kit with a new architecture:

- The architecture is built in layers — a framework-agnostic core (`@dnd-kit/abstract`), a DOM implementation (`@dnd-kit/dom`), and thin adapters for your framework of choice.
- The community is asking whether there is an ETA for when `@dnd-kit/react` will reach a stable, production-ready release, and whether `@dnd-kit/core` is still considered stable and safe for production use.

### Migration Path (Old → New)

The migration involves replacing `@dnd-kit/core`, `@dnd-kit/sortable`, and `@dnd-kit/utilities` with `@dnd-kit/react` and `@dnd-kit/helpers`. The new `DragDropProvider` replaces the legacy `DndContext`.

## What Should You Do for React 19?

You have several options:

### Option 1: Use `@dnd-kit/react` (new, experimental)
Install the new packages:
```bash
npm install @dnd-kit/react @dnd-kit/helpers
```
This is designed to work with React 19 but is still in **pre-1.0 beta** (v0.2.4).

### Option 2: Use `@dnd-kit/core` with `--legacy-peer-deps`
You can force-install the classic `@dnd-kit/core` v6.3.1 with React 19 using:
```bash
npm install @dnd-kit/core @dnd-kit/sortable --legacy-peer-deps
```
It may work at runtime even though peer dependencies don't officially list React 19, but this is not guaranteed.

### Option 3: Switch to an alternative library
Some projects have resolved the `@dnd-kit` incompatibility by migrating to **pragmatic-drag-and-drop** (from Atlassian), which supports React 19.

## Summary Table

| Package | Latest Version | React 19 Support | Status |
|---------|---------------|-------------------|--------|
| `@dnd-kit/core` | 6.3.1 | ❌ Not officially | Stable but unmaintained |
| `@dnd-kit/sortable` | ~8.0.0 | ❌ Not officially | Stable but unmaintained |
| `@dnd-kit/react` | 0.2.4 | ✅ Yes | Beta/Experimental |
| `pragmatic-drag-and-drop` | — | ✅ Yes | Alternative option |

**Recommendation**: If starting a new project with React 19, either use `@dnd-kit/react` (the new beta) or consider `pragmatic-drag-and-drop` as an alternative. If you have an existing project using `@dnd-kit/core`, you can try `--legacy-peer-deps` as a temporary workaround while evaluating migration options.

Design a detailed, step-by-step implementation plan for a Parcel Tracker web application.

## Current State
- Fresh Next.js 16.1.6 project with App Router
- React 19.2.3, TypeScript 5, Tailwind CSS 4 already configured
- Path alias `@/*` → `./src/*`
- No backend, no database, no auth - just boilerplate
- User does NOT yet have Supabase, TrackingMore API, or SMTP provider accounts

## Full Requirements

### Stack
- Next.js (App Router), React, Supabase, Tailwind CSS
- TrackingMore API for parcel tracking
- Deployment: local + Vercel

### Authentication (Supabase Auth)
- Email/password sign up/login
- 3 roles: Guest (track without account), Registered (track + save + history), Admin (see all users' activity)
- Row-level security at database level

### Tracking
- Enter tracking number → auto-detect courier → user confirms/changes → show status timeline with checkpoints
- Track up to 6 parcels at once
- Form supports add, remove, reorder via drag-and-drop

### History
- Logged-in users: all trackings saved
- History page: see past trackings, refresh any tracking, delete one/many, filter by status, sort by date

### Live Updates
- Supabase Realtime: if user refreshes tracking on one device, other tabs/devices update immediately

### Dashboard
- Summary cards (total trackings, in transit, delivered this month, avg delivery time)
- Chart: tracking volume past 30 days
- Courier breakdown: usage frequency, delivery success rates
- In-transit parcels with quick-refresh
- All stats computed server-side

### Bulk Import
- CSV upload with tracking numbers + optional courier codes
- Validation report → user review → confirm → progress → summary
- Handle large files

### Shareable Tracking Pages
- Unique public URL per tracking showing full timeline
- QR code + OG image for social previews
- Owner can toggle public/private

### Contact Form
- Sends email to configured address
- Server-side validation
- Rate limiting per visitor

### Testing (Playwright)
- Auth flow, tracking (guest + logged-in), history, bulk CSV, public/private toggle
- Run locally, independent of external services

### UI
- Responsive (mobile, tablet, desktop)
- Dark/light mode
- Loading states/skeletons
- Animations for transitions and lists
- Toast notifications
- Empty states

### Constraints
- No client-exposed secrets
- External API calls through own API routes
- TypeScript throughout
- DB: foreign keys, indexes, RLS
- No hardcoded data

## Plan Requirements
Design the plan as a phased development approach with clear, meaningful commit points. Each phase should be:
1. Self-contained and testable
2. Building on the previous phase
3. Resulting in a meaningful commit

Include:
- Dependencies to install for each phase
- Database schema design (Supabase tables, RLS policies)
- File/folder structure
- Key implementation details for complex features
- Which external service setup is needed at each phase

The plan should follow this general order:
1. Project foundation (folder structure, shared components, theme)
2. Supabase setup + Auth
3. Tracking feature
4. History
5. Dashboard
6. Live updates
7. Bulk import
8. Shareable pages
9. Contact form
10. Testing
11. Polish + deployment

Here's a summary of the search results regarding **Recharts, React 19, and Next.js compatibility in 2025**:

---

## Recharts & React 19 Compatibility

To use Recharts with React 19, you will need to override the `react-is` dependency. The `react-is` version needs to match the version of React 19 you are using — this is noted as an example in the shadcn/ui docs. This is a key step when using Recharts in **Next.js 15 + React 19** projects.

## What is Recharts?

Recharts is a redefined chart library built with React and D3. Its main purpose is to help you write charts in React applications without any pain, with the principle of simply deploying with React components.

Recharts is consistently praised for its simplicity, ease of use, and clean SVG rendering. Its strong community support and integration with UI libraries like Mantine contribute to its popularity.

## Recharts in 2025

With over 24.8K stars on GitHub, Recharts is a redefined chart library built with D3 and React. One of the most popular charting libraries for React, Recharts has excellent documentation and follows React's component principle by enabling users to build charts with reusable React components. It provides beautiful charts out of the box that can be customized by tweaking existing component props or adding custom ones.

## Using Recharts with Next.js

Note the `"use client"` directive at the top of the code. This special directive tells Next.js to treat the component as a Client Component. This is because Recharts uses some browser-only APIs that are run on the client-side only. If you don't add this line, you're likely to run into a `TypeError: Super expression must either be null or a function`.

Recharts is a lightweight SVG-based React charting library built on top of D3 submodules, offering composable React components for different kinds of charts.

## Strengths & Limitations

**Strengths:**
- Built specifically for React using JSX syntax for easy integration. SVG-based rendering ensures high-quality visuals with crisp and scalable graphics. Built-in responsiveness adapts well to different screen sizes without extra effort.
- Recharts also offers strong TypeScript support, making it solid for teams using TypeScript in their React projects. The type definitions help catch errors early and provide better developer tooling.

**Limitations:**
- Performance is strong and it can handle large data sets, but it doesn't offer the same level of customization as D3 or ECharts. For that reason, it's recommended for small to medium-sized React projects.
- For basic to moderately complex charts with average-sized datasets, Recharts works well within React's rendering lifecycle. For extremely large datasets or highly dynamic visualizations with frequent updates, you might need additional optimizations or alternatives focused on high-performance rendering.

## Recent Releases (from GitHub)

The latest releases include fixes and performance improvements, as well as the deprecation of Pie `activeShape`/`inactiveShape` in favor of aligning with the `shape` prop of other chart elements.

Recharts v3 has implemented a `reverseStackOrder` prop and various performance improvements.

---

### Key Takeaway for React 19 / Next.js 15

If you're using Recharts with **React 19** and **Next.js 15**, the main thing to know is:
1. **Override the `react-is` dependency** to match your React 19 version (as documented by shadcn/ui).
2. **Use the `"use client"` directive** on any component that renders Recharts charts, since Recharts relies on browser-only APIs.

Links: [{"title":"Fetch Mocking With Playwright in Next.js 15 | Momentic","url":"https://momentic.ai/blog/fetch-mocking-with-playwright-next-js"},{"title":"GitHub - mswjs/playwright: Mock Service Worker binding for Playwright.","url":"https://github.com/mswjs/playwright"},{"title":"Next.js Playwright and MSW E2E Testing","url":"https://www.lazakrisz.hu/blog/nextjs-playwright-msw-testing"},{"title":"playwright-msw - npm","url":"https://www.npmjs.com/package/playwright-msw"},{"title":"Testing React Apps with Playwright + MSW: The Bulletproof Combo You Need in 2025 | by Clean Compiler | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/@REDACTED"},{"title":"Provide handler in test that interacts with server-side NextJS code · mswjs/msw · Discussion #1431","url":"https://github.com/mswjs/msw/discussions/1431"},{"title":"End-to-End test with Nextjs, Playwright and MSW — Real-time Open Source Software Supply Chain Security","url":"https://safedep.io/end-to-end-test-nextjs-msw-playwright/"},{"title":"Testing: Playwright | Next.js","url":"https://nextjs.org/docs/pages/guides/testing/playwright"},{"title":"Getting Started | mswjs/playwright | DeepWiki","url":"https://deepwiki.com/mswjs/playwright/2-getting-started"},{"title":"How to setup server side mocking for your Next.js application with Playwright tests in minutes with Mocky Balboa | by Lewis Nelson | Medium","url":"https://lewis-38728.medium.com/how-to-setup-server-side-mocking-for-your-next-js-2a5aaf214ef7"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of setting up Playwright with Next.js and MSW (Mock Service Worker) for testing:

## Playwright + Next.js + MSW Testing Setup

### Three Main Approaches

There are currently three main approaches for integrating Playwright with MSW in Next.js applications:

---

### 1. Next.js Experimental `testProxy` (Recommended for Server-Side Mocking)

An experimental feature in Next.js 15 makes this process easier using Playwright and MSW. This is particularly important for Next.js App Router where server components make fetch calls that can't be intercepted client-side.

**Configuration (`next.config.ts`):**

You need to enable the experimental `testProxy` in your Next.js config:
```ts
// next.config.ts
import type { NextConfig } from "next";
const nextConfig: NextConfig = {
  experimental: { testProxy: true },
};
export default nextConfig;
```
This tells Next to use the experimental testProxy.

**Writing Tests:**

This approach supports testing Server Components (external API calls), testing Server Actions, testing GraphQL Queries and Mutations using Apollo Client, and E2E-Testing with Drizzle and Server Components. You import test utilities directly from `next/experimental/testmode/playwright/msw`.

**Key Gotchas:**
- Some SSR requests can run before handlers are registered, so they hit real services in CI. Fix: register MSW handlers before any navigation.
- In practice, `passthrough` caused instability in testmode (including Request reuse errors). The pattern that worked consistently was `bypass`, which routes a request to the real network without breaking the proxy pipeline.
- When using testProxy, there seems to be an issue with types, especially when using scope with the `mswHandlers` option. You can use the worker scope, however currently it gives you a TypeScript error.

---

### 2. `@msw/playwright` (Official MSW Package)

This is the official Mock Service Worker binding for Playwright.

The `@msw/playwright` package requires Node.js 20.0.0 or higher and has msw version 2.10.3 or higher as a peer dependency.

Until cross-process request interception ships, `@msw/playwright` relies on the `page.route()` API to provision the request interception in your tests.

**Setup involves extending Playwright's test fixtures:**

The setup process involves extending Playwright's test fixtures to include a network fixture that provides MSW functionality within your test context. The `NetworkFixture` supports dynamic handler registration using the `network.use()` method.

It uses `page.route()` as the source of the network to route through the handlers and supports both `http` and `graphql` namespaces.

---

### 3. `playwright-msw` (Community Package)

This is a community-built MSW integration layer for Playwright that intercepts and mocks network requests performed by browsers during Playwright test execution.

It runs within the context of an individual test; mocks can be safely manipulated on a per-test basis without interfering with others executing in parallel.

As of version 3, `playwright-msw` has been updated to utilize MSW 2.x. In order to utilize the latest version, you must update your tests to use the new syntax.

---

### Key Architectural Considerations

For client-side rendering, you could use Playwright's built-in `page.route()`. But for server-side rendering, you must proxy your requests. This is where the experimental fetch mocking and MSW come in.

The test process (Playwright) and the Next server process are two different processes. You cannot directly access any data in the server process unless there's some sort of communication channel implemented explicitly by both parties.

If you are building a server-heavy Next.js app, the biggest mindset shift is this: your "frontend tests" are actually server tests.

### Best Practices

- Treat the server as the test boundary in App Router apps. Mock RPC boundaries, not server actions.
- Prefer `bypass` to `passthrough` in Next testmode.
- Keep experimental tooling isolated and swappable.
- Use shared `mswHandlers` patterns to share mocks across tests.
- Run `npm run build` and `npm run start`, then run `npx playwright test` in another terminal window to run the Playwright tests.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here's a comprehensive overview of **qrcode.react** and its React 19 compatibility:

## qrcode.react — React 19 Compatible QR Code Generator

### React 19 Support

**qrcode.react** has added React v19 to its `peerDependencies` (PR #381), confirming official compatibility with React 19.

### Latest Version

It is a React component to generate QR codes, with the latest version being **4.2.0**.

### Installation

You can start using qrcode.react in your project by running `npm i qrcode.react`. There are 1,182 other projects in the npm registry using qrcode.react.

### Components

qrcode.react exports two components, supporting rendering as SVG or Canvas. SVG is generally recommended as it is more flexible, but Canvas may be preferable in certain use cases.

### Key Features (v4.x)

- Support for a new `boostLevel` prop, allowing the disabling of the underlying encoder's default of automatically boosting the ECL, and support for accepting an array of strings for `value`, which enables encoding of each part into independent segments.
- Improved support for dual publishing of ESM/CJS modules for better compatibility with tools.
- Mitigated warnings when using QRCodeSVG in server components.
- Added proper support for `ref`, enabling direct access to underlying canvas or SVG nodes, which also resulted in much more accurate type definitions.

### Props

Key props accepted by both `QRCodeSVG` and `QRCodeCanvas`:

| Prop | Type | Default | Description |
|------|------|---------|-------------|
| `value` | `string \| string[]` | — | The value to encode |
| `size` | `number` | 128 | Size in pixels |
| `level` | `'L' \| 'M' \| 'Q' \| 'H'` | `'L'` | Error correction level |
| `bgColor` | `string` | `#FFFFFF` | Background color |
| `fgColor` | `string` | `#000000` | Foreground color |
| `marginSize` | `number` | 0 | Number of modules for margin |
| `title` | `string` | — | Accessibility title |
| `imageSettings` | `object` | — | Embedded image configuration |

### Alternatives

If you're looking for other React QR code packages:

- **react-qr-code** (v2.0.18) — A QR code generator for React and React Native.
- **react-qrcode-logo** — A TypeScript React component to generate a customizable QR Code. For React version >= 18, use react-qrcode-logo version >= 3.0.0.

### Summary

**qrcode.react** is the most popular and actively maintained React QR code generation package, with confirmed React 19 support in version 4.2.0. It offers both SVG and Canvas rendering, embedded image support, server component compatibility, and full TypeScript type definitions.
